reviews.text:
Virupaksha Temple in Hampi is one of the most iconic and sacred landmarks in the region, and my visit here left a lasting impression. I happened to explore it during a hot summer afternoon, which I wouldn't recommend to others-ideally, visit early in the morning or around sunset when the weather is more forgiving and the lighting enhances the beauty of the structure.

Despite the heat, the grandeur of the temple was undeniable. The towering gopuram (gateway tower) can be seen from a distance and is truly magnificent. Inside, the temple complex offers intricate carvings, pillars with beautiful motifs, and an active place of worship that has been functional for centuries. There's a spiritual aura in the temple that adds to the overall experience.

I especially liked observing the architectural symmetry and how well-preserved most parts of the structure are despite the passage of time. The surrounding area is bustling with pilgrims, locals, and tourists, so expect a lively atmosphere. The temple elephant is also a special sight for many visitors.

If you're in Hampi, Virupaksha Temple is not to be missed. Just make sure to plan your visit during cooler hours to fully appreciate its beauty and significance without being exhausted by the sun.

Virupaksha temple is famous for architecture, big gopuras,and historical significance.This pilgrimage site is a part of UNESCO World heritage site.

Till today the pooja is done for the lord Shiva in the name of Virupaksha and celebrates annual festivals.
This Temple surroundings are kept clean and well maintained.

Temple timings is from 6:00 AM to 9:00 PM temple will be opened all days.

The Ugra Narasimha Swamy statue in Hampi, Karnataka, is one of the most iconic and imposing sculptures in the ruined city, a UNESCO World Heritage site. Standing at an impressive height of 6.7 meters (about 22 feet), it is the largest monolithic statue in Hampi, carved from a single boulder. It was built in 1528 AD during the reign of King Krishnadevaraya, one of the greatest rulers of the Vijayanagara Empire. The temple and statue were originally dedicated to both Lord Narasimha and Goddess Lakshmi, hence it's also known as the Lakshmi Narasimha Temple.

Elephant Stables in Hampi are a must-see attraction that showcases the region's rich history and architectural brilliance. These ancient stables, built to house the royal elephants, are a testament to the ingenuity and craftsmanship of the Vijayanagara Empire. As you walk through the stables, you'll be struck by the intricate carvings, ornate arches, and majestic domes that adorn the structure. The stables' robust design and imposing architecture evoke a sense of wonder, transporting you back in time to an era of royal grandeur. Imagine the royal elephants that once called this place home, their gentle giants roaming the grounds. With its rich history, stunning architecture, and fascinating stories to tell, Elephant Stables is a great spot for history buffs, architecture enthusiasts, and anyone looking to explore the wonders of Hampi.

reviews.text:
The Lotus Mahal, located in Hampi, India, is a stunning example of the unique architectural style of the Vijayanagara Empire. It's a beautiful structure that stands out due to its distinctive design, resembling a lotus flower.

The Mahal combines elements of both Indian and Islamic architectural styles, showcasing the cultural synthesis of the time. Its base is geometric, with arched windows and balconies that create a delicate and elegant appearance. The roof is designed in a pyramidal shape, with multiple levels that add to the lotus-like impression.

The interior of the Lotus Mahal is equally impressive, with intricately carved arches and stucco work. The structure was likely used for various purposes, including meetings and as a recreational space for the royal family. The cool, airy environment provided a comfortable retreat from the hot climate.

The Lotus Mahal is a must-see attraction in Hampi, offering a glimpse into the artistic and architectural achievements of the Vijayanagara Empire. Its unique design and historical significance make it a true gem of Indian heritage.

As you walk around the palace, you'll notice the attention to detail in every aspect of its design, from the delicate patterns on the walls to the ornate pillars that support the structure. Surrounded by lush greenery, the palace offers a peaceful atmosphere perfect for relaxation and photography, making it an ideal spot to unwind and soak in the beauty of Hampi. Visited Nov 2024.
One of the largest temple complexes in Hampi along with Pattabhirama temple. Enough has been written about this place so I won't repeat. Just visit this place ! Allocate at least one hour for this site, apart from the main shrine there are smaller temples and columned rest houses. There is a small temple to the south of this place with a 10-armed goddess - it is a active temple, worth a visit (small door in the south outer perimeter get you there).

The Achyutaraya Temple also known as Tiruvengalanatha (a form of Lord Vishnu) temple, built in 1534 AD by Mahamandeleshwara Hiriya Tirumalraja during the reign of Achyutadeva Raya, is situated in the foothills between the Matanga and Gandhamadhavan hills. Mythically, these hills are associated with the curse of Matanga Rishi due to which Bali could not enter this area and hence the area was a safe haven for Sugriva.

The temple complex includes the main temple as well as associated bazaar and pushkarni (pond). The main temple consists of sanctum sanctorum, antaral, mandap, Devi temple and kalyana mandap. The temple is surrounded by two prakaras. The outer prakara has one gopuram (entrance) and the inner prakara has three gopurams. The open chamber outside the temple is formed by finely carved pillars. The kalyana mandap is also adorned with highly carved pillars.

The distinctive feature of Vijayanagara temples are the tall gopurams and Kalyana mandapams. Over time the gopurams became increasingly taller, in most cases even higher than the vimana (spire) of the temple. The Kalyana mandapam was built to perform the annual marriage ceremony between the main deity and the goddess. The pillars of the Kalyana mandapam have some of the most magnificent carvings. In temples of this period, the sanctum and gopuram walls are built of stone while the vimana is built of bricks.

This was one of the best places I visited in Hampi. Many people miss this amazing temple since there is no direct road to it, and you have walk from Kodandarama Temple. There was absolutely no one in this temple when I visited (Jul 2025), and I could explore the ruins on my own. This is a pretty large temple complex, and it can be seen from the top of Mathanga hill. It's a bit desolate so be careful here and preferably travel with a group.
There is a pathway leading from this temple to Mathanga Hill, but I did not use it to hike up the hill. If you are visiting Hampi, make sure to visit this hidden gem.

places.name: Underground Shiva Temple

reviews.text:
üìç The Underground Shiva Temple, Hampi ||

One of the lesser-known but immensely fascinating sites in Hampi is the underground Shiva Temple, also known as the Prasanna Virupaksha Temple.

Built sometime around 14th Century AD under the reign of King Deva Raya II, this temple, like all the other surviving temples in Hampi, is noted for its impressive architecture and also a large monolithic lingam of Lord Shiva located inside a circular chamber.

It is worth noting that the circular chamber was carved out of a single rock, and the roof is supported by four pillars also carved out of the same rock, bearing testimony to both the assiduousness and patience of the architects who painstakingly built this temple.

This temple also had a unique water management system, with water channels built around the Shiva lingam to ensure it remains constantly immersed in water. This is believed to symbolise the origin of the Tungabhadra River from the matted hair lock of Lord Shiva.

Another interesting fact about this temple is that it was intentionally built underground to protect it from invaders. Visitors can witness intricate carvings on the walls and pillars. This temple is considered a hidden gem in Hampi and definitely worth a visit for those who love history, architecture, and most importantly, Hindu mythology.

The temple is dedicated to Prasanna Virupaksha, an avatar of Lord Shiva. The temple stands amidst a beautiful lawn covered in green.
The temple has remained buried for over four hundred years before it was discovered in the 1980's decade. It is believed that Vijayanagara ruler Krishnadevaraya had donated extensively to this temple.
the sanctum of the temple remains submerged under stagnant water throughout the year. During the monsoon season, extending from June to August, the water level rises inside the temple and submerges the floor of the maha mantapa and other mantapas.
This restricts the entry of visitors to most parts of the temple during the rainy season.
Opens on 6 am and closes on 6 pm.

Hazara Rama Temple in Hampi is a captivating gem that beautifully showcases the artistry of the Vijayanagara Empire. Built in the early 15th century, this temple was originally a private worship site for the royal family and is dedicated to Lord Rama. Its name, meaning "a thousand Ramayana," reflects the extensive bas-reliefs adorning its walls, which narrate the epic story of Ramayana in intricate detail.

As you approach, the temple's stunning architecture and serene surroundings immediately draw you in. The outer walls are richly decorated with scenes of royal processions, military displays, and divine figures, offering a glimpse into the grandeur of its historical context. The craftsmanship is exceptional, with ornately carved pillars and a spacious lawn enhancing its charm.

Visiting Hazara Rama Temple is free, and photography is encouraged, making it an ideal spot for both history enthusiasts and casual tourists. The temple is open daily from 6 AM to 6 PM, with the best time to visit being between November and February. Overall, Hazara Rama Temple is a must-see for anyone exploring Hampi's rich cultural heritage.

‚Ä¢	üìç Location: Situated on the slopes of Hemakuta Hill, near Virupaksha Temple in Hampi (a UNESCO World Heritage Site).
‚Ä¢	ü™® Structure: The idol is carved out of a single huge granite boulder.
‚Ä¢	üêò Form: The belly of the Ganesha idol resembles a kadalekai (Bengal gram / groundnut), hence the name Kadalekalu Ganesha.

The Kadalekalu Ganesha Temple in Hampi was amazing. The giant Ganesha statue, carved from one huge boulder, is so impressive-it stands at 4.5 meters tall and really grabs your attention.

The temple is also really beautiful. The tall pillars inside are decorated with cool mythological carvings, and the whole place has a peaceful, ancient vibe. Walking around, I felt connected to the rich history of Hampi, especially with the old ruins surrounding it.

If you're in Hampi, definitely check out this temple. It's a peaceful spot with so much history!

reviews.text: Hampi bazaar is something which is a common eye sight throughout hampi journey. Bazar is something which is quiet live. Imagine a long, wide street, flanked by ancient pillared structures that once housed bustling shops and royal pavilions. Today, it's still alive and kicking, though perhaps a little less grand than its 15th-century heyday. But trust me, the vibe is still absolutely infectious! You'll find a mix of local vendors, small cafes, and guesthouses, all humming with activity. It's the perfect place to soak in the local atmosphere. üö∂‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èüö∂‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

What can you find here? Well, it's a treasure trove of local crafts! Think vibrant textiles, traditional Lambani jewelry (so unique and pretty! ‚ú®), stone carvings that echo the artistry of the temples, and all sorts of quirky souvenirs to remember your trip by. Don't be shy to haggle a little; it's part of the fun! üòâ You'll also spot plenty of fresh fruit stalls and small eateries serving up delicious South Indian snacks and meals. Grab a fresh coconut water ‚Äì it's a lifesaver in the Hampi heat! ü••ü•≠

One of the coolest things about Hampi Bazaar is its history. Just standing there, you can almost picture horses, elephants, and merchants from distant lands trading spices and precious gems. It's a living archaeological site! Plus, the view of the Virupaksha Temple's gopuram towering over one end of the bazaar is simply breathtaking, especially during sunrise or sunset. reviews.text:
The Nandi Stone Statue at the base of Matanga Hill is a must-visit when in Hampi. This massive and beautifully carved Nandi statue, hewn from a single monolithic rock, is an impressive sight. The intricate detailing, including the finely carved tail, showcases the remarkable craftsmanship of the time.

One of the unique aspects of this spot is the view-if you sit on the steps in front of the statue, you'll see the Virupaksha Temple perfectly aligned in a straight line, creating a stunning visual connection between these iconic landmarks.

For those looking to explore more, a flight of steps on the left side of the Nandi pavilion leads to the historic Achyuta Raya's Temple, located across the hill.

This spot offers not only a glimpse into ancient art but also serves as a serene starting point for exploring Hampi's rich heritage. Don't miss it!

During my exploration of Hampi, I made it a point to visit the iconic Nandi statue situated near the base of the Matanga Hill. This monolithic statue of Nandi, the sacred bull and vehicle of Lord Shiva, is truly a majestic sight to behold. Carved out of a single stone, it exudes a sense of ancient strength and devotion that fits perfectly with the mystical ruins of Hampi.

The Nandi statue sits peacefully, facing the Virupaksha Temple, symbolizing loyalty and divine presence. Though the area around it is often filled with tourists and pilgrims, it still manages to maintain a tranquil aura. The craftsmanship is impressive-despite centuries of weathering, the intricate detailing on the body, especially the ornaments, is still visible and admirable.

Surrounding the statue, you'll find a calm, open space with a backdrop of rocky boulders and scattered ruins that give you a feel of Hampi's historic grandeur. It's also a good spot to take a short break from all the walking while soaking in the view of the temple in the distance.

If you're climbing Matanga Hill for a sunrise or sunset view, this Nandi is a perfect prelude to the journey. It's not just a statue-it's a symbol of devotion and a perfect blend of art, culture, and history that makes Hampi so memorable.

Single stone monolithic statue of Nandi facing Virupaksha temple devoted to lord Shiva. Hampi Bazaar is located on both sides of the road from Nandi to Virupaksha Temple.This large Nandi bull statue is located at the eastern end of the bazaar.
